q1.correctFeedback: Correct! "It’s important to remember that just because communities of speakers use common language doesn't mean that those speakers share the exact same conceptualization of each object that’s designated... If asked to draw their conceptualization of a table, no two individual speakers of a language will draw the same one from the mental inventory of those they’ve encountered or imagined in their lives. This is significant because those outside the language services and localization professions assume that meaning is held within the designation, but words themselves are arbitrary and empty. Meaning truly is in the eye or brain of the beholder." (Alaina Brandt, Getting Started with Terminology Management, The ATA Chronicle)
